stream_context.summary: Kaze spends the majority of the stream prototyping a new ‘tropical-beach’ water system for the overworld, while briefly revealing that he just finished a complete rewrite of Mario 64’s audio engine.

development_findings.summary: Kaze completely rewrote Mario 64’s audio engine this week; it is now more memory-efficient, easier to debug, and almost entirely his own code, with only the RSP interface still using Nintendo code.
Because the audio engine code is original, Kaze believes it can legally be reused in an independent game once the RSP interface is also rewritten.
development_findings.quote: As long as we change the way we interface with the RSP as well… I think we’re fine legally to just use this in our own game now.

development_findings.summary: Current stream task: create convincing beach water for the overworld—including directional waves, depth tinting, and shoreline foam—using dynamic vertex manipulation rather than fixed sine-wave scrolling.

Initial approach experimented with Gerstner waves but was abandoned for performance; Kaze settled on a custom hex-tessellated ring mesh (~600–3,000 triangles after culling) whose vertices rise and fall based on distance from an island center.
He plans to add foam by mapping a separate texture to shoreline vertices and modulating opacity by the vertex’s downward velocity.
Target ROM size is 64 MB—matching late-life N64 cartridges—allowing more ambitious assets than early hacks limited to 8 MB.
Return to Yoshi’s Island is being kept console-compatible, in contrast to many earlier Mario 64 hacks (e.g., Star Road) that broke on real hardware due to older tools.
development_findings.quote: Most of my romhacks are not console compatible… This one is.

development_findings.summary: Design rationale for the project’s theme is simple: Kaze personally loves Yoshi.
development_findings.quote: I like Yoshi. That’s kind of where the thought process ended.

context_findings.summary: Kaze views the Mario 64 hacking scene as formerly marginal within wider homebrew and wants this project to meet higher technical standards.
context_findings.quote: For the longest time the Mario 64 community was like such a pathetic part of the homebrew community.

context_findings.summary: He balances development with family life; mentions nine-month-old baby and Easter plans.
Accidental weight loss of ~20 lbs (215 → 194) noted; indicates health awareness.
Expresses both pride and frustration when chat critiques shader terminology and visual choices, revealing perfectionist tendencies.

biobak.summary: Offers technical suggestions during the water discussion—e.g., doubling outer-ring vertices, foam implementation, and keeping waves smooth for swimming.

key_stories.title: Audio Engine Overhaul
key_stories.summary: Over the prior week Kaze rewrote Mario 64’s entire audio engine, making it his own code, cutting memory use, and enabling faster debugging. Only Nintendo’s RSP interface remains.
key_stories.challenge: Original audio system was opaque, inefficient, and legally entangled.
key_stories.process: Refactored every component and rewrote functionality from scratch.
key_stories.outcome: Near-final new engine that can be ported legally; boosts confidence for future debugging.
key_stories.key_quote: It’s a lot more memory efficient… and now I understand the whole codebase.

key_stories.title: Chasing the Perfect Water
key_stories.summary: During the stream Kaze iterates through multiple water-rendering strategies, balancing visual quality, swimming mechanics, and N64 performance limits.
key_stories.challenge: Create directional tropical waves without exceeding vertex budgets or breaking Mario’s swimming.
key_stories.process: Tested flat scrolling textures, examined Wind Waker references, rejected Gerstner waves, built a custom hex-tessellated mesh with distance-based sine movement, added depth tinting, and planned foam overlay.
key_stories.outcome: Achieved an attractive prototype (≈600 visible triangles) and a clear roadmap for foam and collision tweaks.
key_stories.key_quote: It’s kind of crazy how easy it is to make a map look good if you just have good shaders… or good fixed-function pipelines.
